messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Yes, that s it -- thanks.  You can tell that there s some relief from the straight-on view, but not how high it really is until you get a view from the
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
Yes, that's it -- thanks. You can tell that there's some relief from the straight-on view, but not how high it really is until you get a view from the side.

Also it's not just high relief, but very straight walled. Goto Joshin also did pieces with high relief, but his carving style used that height for three dimensional modeling. His volumes are large overall.

Ko-Mino has a unique look.

Jim



Jim -

Here are a couple (not so good) pictures of a kozuka that I've had for years that I've always considered ko-Mino because of the high raised and cut design. One photo shows the face of the kozuka, the other its profile showing the greatly raised design. Maybe this will explain what you've been saying, maybe not. Please, comments welcomed!

http://tinyurl.com/27m5c

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim - I think this reference to weight was something John Yumoto said and he was talking about (shakudo) Soten tsuba at the time, if memory serves. Ron STL
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim -

I think this reference to weight was something John Yumoto said and he was talking about (shakudo) Soten tsuba at the time, if memory serves.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 08, 2004 6:05 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba


Milt,
Copper is a bit more dense than iron, and gold of course is more than twice as dense as copper. But given the relatively small percentage of gold in even high quality shakudo, I doubt that it'd be practical to do kantei by weight.

I'm not sure how a copper alloy plate from Mino or decorated in Mino style would have a different weight from one of comparable size decorated somewhere else. If anything, the deeply cut type of Mino-bori tsuba could tend to feel a little lighter than expected for its size due to the material removed.

Fortunately kantei of Mino work by visual cues is pretty reliable.
Jim
-------------------------------
Gang,
An advance collector told me the " weight " plays a part in the
kantei too......... mino works are supposed to be " heavy ".

Jim et al, your thoughts on this ?


Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy, I think yours is Edo period.  So, just Mino.  Some Ko-Mino can be much more deeply carved than yours.  It s not really a deep marubori though.  The
messages.messageBody:
Darcy,
I think yours is Edo period. So, just Mino. Some Ko-Mino can be much more deeply carved than yours. It's not really a deep marubori though. The sides of the carving are very straight, without modeling. The details of the motif will be carved with a relatively moderate amount of relief, but the background is carved way down so that the figures are standing up high. It's sort of like a shadow box effect. Not sure if that makes sense. This can be hard to see in illustrations, since the depth isn't apparent in a straight-on photo. The first time you see one of this type from the side it can be surprising.

Always good to see more Mino fittings.
Jim


Interesting info.

So when you look at mine, do you see just a deeply carved Mino piece, or
do you see enough for you to think this is ko Mino? It seems to be some
of the standard theme stuff so I didn't think it older.

I don't know anything about fittings. I have an interest in stuff with
bugs on it, and that tends to be some of these Mino things, and I
remember being told about the deep carving.

I've got some other examples I can put up of Mino stuff...

- darcy


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... sections taken from copper alloy artifacts to identify forged vs. cast, vs. hot worked cast, vs. cold worked cast, etc., from the details of the crystal
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Rich,
> Archaeometallurgists spend a lot of time looking at etched cross
sections taken from copper alloy artifacts to identify forged vs.
cast, vs. hot worked cast, vs. cold worked cast, etc., from the
details of the crystal structure. It should be possible to get proof
given an analyst and a piece to section.
>
> Jim

Jim -

I'm basing my guess that Nagoya-mono tsuba are cast plates
with hand finishing, solely on the fact that the relief work
is always the same while the detail work varies slightly.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mino " style " fuchi ?
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, They are typical Mino fuchi, but not very high quality.  The motif, the high relief carving, the bands at the top and bottom and the construction are all
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
They are typical Mino fuchi, but not very high quality. The motif, the high relief carving, the bands at the top and bottom and the construction are all Mino. They look like Edo period work. There are some better examples of this type from the Edo period with Mino signatures. I don't think that there's anything to do with Goto, though. Valid examples of the Mino style.

Jim


http://tinyurl.com/365t5

goto-mino ?
very " deep " carving................

milt

Matt,
Seeing them in person is the most important. I'll look for any illustrations that could do a reasonable job of capturing the differences.

BTW, I think the commonly used "Mino Goto" term may be confusing things. We're talking about Mino. Mino from before the Edo period is Ko-Mino.
Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy, Ko-Mino (i.e. pre Edo period Mino) does tend to be very deeply carved.  The walls of the carving are often very straight -- it s not a maru-bori style.
messages.messageBody:
Darcy,
Ko-Mino (i.e. pre Edo period Mino) does tend to be very deeply carved. The walls of the carving are often very straight -- it's not a maru-bori style. Ko-Mino work can have even deeper relief than your kashira, but not all do. Thanks for putting your piece up.

"Kinko Mino Bori" by Kokubo Kenichi 1973, Token Shunjo Shinbunsha, Tokyo is a good reference. The 1993 Kinko Mino Bori special exhibition catalog from the Gifu museum is even better.
Jim

--------------------
I had also been told that the carving was very deep. Lesser stuff is not
carved so deeply.

http://www.xhasc.com/nihonto/kashira.jpg

Is my example. The bug there is so high off the background he's casting
quite a shadow.

- darcy



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Archaeometallurgists spend a lot of time looking at etched cross sections taken from copper alloy artifacts to identify forged vs. cast, vs. hot worked
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Archaeometallurgists spend a lot of time looking at etched cross sections taken from copper alloy artifacts to identify forged vs. cast, vs. hot worked cast, vs. cold worked cast, etc., from the details of the crystal structure. It should be possible to get proof given an analyst and a piece to section.

Jim

I suspect (no proof) that these were actually cast bases
with hand finishing on the nanako and gold work. The nanako
is usually quite large and uneven; figural work is rounded
rather than sharply carved, gold/silver onlay commonly
"runs into" the nanako plate.
>
Rich S

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... Ron - I suspect (again no proof) that much of what we see in fittings, especially tsuba, are not one ofs . I seen just too many of the exact same design
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@u...>
>.... What I've always felt the book shows is how (almost?)
>"mass produced" so much of this work was.

Ron -

I suspect (again no proof) that much of what we see in fittings,
especially tsuba, are not "one ofs". I seen just too many of
the exact same design in too many tsuba. I suspect most of what
we see are "school" pieces and pattern book work; even for
the major schools like Saotome, Umetada, Higo, Owari, Kyo-Shoami
and Kyo-Sukashi, etc.

I'm not real sure just where the line is between "original"
work and "pattern book or school" work. It seems very blurred.

Rich S

------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: mino " style " fuchi ?
messages.msgSnippet: ... tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of brown.  The carving is very crisp and precise, the nanako perfectly formed and the gold
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Rich and Milt,
> I've seen plenty worse, too. For real, high quality Mino (or Goto)
tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of
brown. The carving is very crisp and precise, the nanako perfectly
formed and the gold thick with rich color. Putting a good one next
to a lesser one makes the difference much more clear than I can hope
to describe. I borrowed two tsuba to do that at the SF show with a
few people when we were talking about exactly this topic.
>
> Seeing this one in person would help of course, but I think it
falls short. The somewhat sloppy carving of the insects and plants
looks like shiiremono work. I agree that it is much better than the
worst of the so-called Nagoya-mono. That said, I have seen a few
pieces of this type that I didn't think were too hot, but got Hozon
level attribution to later Mino. I suppose that there is overlap
between the better Mino-style production work and lesser "genuine"
Mino. There is a chance that Milt's piece could paper as later Mino
(even without free drinks) if it's better than the photo suggests. I
don't think that it is representative of high quality Mino work
though.
>
> Does that make any sense?
>
> Jim
>
>
please klick.........

http://tinyurl.com/365t5

goto-mino ?
very " deep " carving................

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ah yes, another to-do article that never got off the ground! For years, I ve found these Mino tsuba rather interesting and have accumulated a group of them
messages.messageBody:
Ah yes, another "to-do" article that never got off the ground! For years, I've found these Mino tsuba rather interesting and have accumulated a group of them of various qualities. My thinking was to put together an article comparing them to one another but I wouldn't hold my breath waiting for it! There is a small-ish book titled "Mino-bori" (I think thats the title) that shows a lot of the Mino work and dates the works. What I've always felt the book shows is how (almost?) "mass produced" so much of this work was. Interesting little book. Yamanaka translated it for me years ago. (It seems I gave that translation to somebody for editing and eventual publication, but if so, I don't recall who that was!) A lot of the brief text is pretty easy to understand, however. While not all such work can be called "excellent" I still find it interesting to study.

Ron
STL

From: Matthew E. Hoyle

Right time for me to ask some stupid novice questions.

1. what is shiiremono work?

2. what is Nagoya-mono work?

3. Could someone perhaps do a photo comparison for the list between
genuine (16th century?) Mino goto stuff and later rubbish copies? I
think that would be extremely educational. Just like what you did at the
SF show Jim?

thanks, Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: zaterdag 3 januari 2004 19:24
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba


Rich and Milt,
I've seen plenty worse, too. For real, high quality Mino (or Goto)
tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of brown.
The carving is very crisp and precise, the nanako perfectly formed and
the gold thick with rich color. Putting a good one next to a lesser one
makes the difference much more clear than I can hope to describe. I
borrowed two tsuba to do that at the SF show with a few people when we
were talking about exactly this topic.

Seeing this one in person would help of course, but I think it falls
short. The somewhat sloppy carving of the insects and plants looks like
shiiremono work. I agree that it is much better than the worst of the
so-called Nagoya-mono. That said, I have seen a few pieces of this type
that I didn't think were too hot, but got Hozon level attribution to
later Mino. I suppose that there is overlap between the better
Mino-style production work and lesser "genuine" Mino. There is a chance
that Milt's piece could paper as later Mino (even without free drinks)
if it's better than the photo suggests. I don't think that it is
representative of high quality Mino work though.

Does that make any sense?

Jim

Jim -

Why do you call this shiiremono? The quality looks a lot
better than what I've seen of this shiiremono genre?
What details of the tsuba say it's shiiremono?

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... Ready made, off the shelf work, usually conjures up visions of poor quality, mass production pieces. ... See
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Matthew E. Hoyle"
<matthewhoyle@w...> wrote:
> Right time for me to ask some stupid novice questions.
>
> 1. what is shiiremono work?

Ready made, off the shelf work, usually conjures up
visions of poor quality, mass production pieces.

>
> 2. what is Nagoya-mono work?

See http://home.earthlink.net/~ttstein/nagoya2.jpg


I suspect (no proof) that these were actually cast bases
with hand finishing on the nanako and gold work. The nanako
is usually quite large and uneven; figural work is rounded
rather than sharply carved, gold/silver onlay commonly
"runs into" the nanako plate.
>
Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Right time for me to ask some stupid novice questions. 1. what is shiiremono work? 2. what is Nagoya-mono work? 3. Could someone perhaps do a photo comparison
messages.messageBody:
Right time for me to ask some stupid novice questions.

1. what is shiiremono work?

2. what is Nagoya-mono work?

3. Could someone perhaps do a photo comparison for the list between
genuine (16th century?) Mino goto stuff and later rubbish copies? I
think that would be extremely educational. Just like what you did at the
SF show Jim?

thanks, Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: zaterdag 3 januari 2004 19:24
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: (unknown) mino-style tsuba


Rich and Milt,
I've seen plenty worse, too. For real, high quality Mino (or Goto)
tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of brown.
The carving is very crisp and precise, the nanako perfectly formed and
the gold thick with rich color. Putting a good one next to a lesser one
makes the difference much more clear than I can hope to describe. I
borrowed two tsuba to do that at the SF show with a few people when we
were talking about exactly this topic.

Seeing this one in person would help of course, but I think it falls
short. The somewhat sloppy carving of the insects and plants looks like
shiiremono work. I agree that it is much better than the worst of the
so-called Nagoya-mono. That said, I have seen a few pieces of this type
that I didn't think were too hot, but got Hozon level attribution to
later Mino. I suppose that there is overlap between the better
Mino-style production work and lesser "genuine" Mino. There is a chance
that Milt's piece could paper as later Mino (even without free drinks)
if it's better than the photo suggests. I don't think that it is
representative of high quality Mino work though.

Does that make any sense?

Jim

Jim -

Why do you call this shiiremono? The quality looks a lot
better than what I've seen of this shiiremono genre?
What details of the tsuba say it's shiiremono?

Rich S

messages.msgSnippet: Rich and Milt, I ve seen plenty worse, too.  For real, high quality Mino (or Goto) tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of brown.  The
messages.messageBody:
Rich and Milt,
I've seen plenty worse, too. For real, high quality Mino (or Goto) tsuba the color of the shakudo is pure black without a trace of brown. The carving is very crisp and precise, the nanako perfectly formed and the gold thick with rich color. Putting a good one next to a lesser one makes the difference much more clear than I can hope to describe. I borrowed two tsuba to do that at the SF show with a few people when we were talking about exactly this topic.

Seeing this one in person would help of course, but I think it falls short. The somewhat sloppy carving of the insects and plants looks like shiiremono work. I agree that it is much better than the worst of the so-called Nagoya-mono. That said, I have seen a few pieces of this type that I didn't think were too hot, but got Hozon level attribution to later Mino. I suppose that there is overlap between the better Mino-style production work and lesser "genuine" Mino. There is a chance that Milt's piece could paper as later Mino (even without free drinks) if it's better than the photo suggests. I don't think that it is representative of high quality Mino work though.

Does that make any sense?

Jim

Jim -

Why do you call this shiiremono? The quality looks a lot
better than what I've seen of this shiiremono genre?
What details of the tsuba say it's shiiremono?

Rich S
